BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the often deep wind slabs represent the main danger. Without question, it is inadvisable to engage in backcountry touring.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects large and, in many cases, very large avalanches are possible as a consequence of the precipitation. Gliding avalanches are possible in particular on steep grassy slopes. The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
Exposed parts of transportation routes can be endangered in some localities in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The large quantity of fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and weakly bonded old snow represent the main danger. Gliding avalanches and loose snow avalanches are to be expected.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
A very large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes large wind slabs that are being formed by the moderate to strong southerly wind can be released very easily in all aspects above the tree line. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable because of the poor visibility. Individual large natural avalanches are possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude shady starting zones. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m.

As the day progresses more frequent medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large loose snow avalanches are to be expected, in the event of prolonged bright spells especially. On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Up to 70 cm of snow fell on Friday above approximately 1500 m. The southerly wind will transport the new snow significantly. The fresh wind slabs will be deposited on soft layers in all aspects.

In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m, as well as on steep north facing slopes above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The weather conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the near-surface layers. More loose snow avalanches are to be expected as the day progresses, in particular medium-sized ones, in the event of solar radiation especially on extremely steep sunny slopes.
The danger of gliding avalanches will persist, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2400 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Gradual increase in avalanche danger as a consequence of the snowfall.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow as well as the large wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls can be released very easily in all aspects above approximately 1800 m. As a consequence of the snowfall, the likelihood of ground avalanches being released will increase gradually in particular on steep southeast and southwest facing slopes at intermediate altitudes. The soft wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence above approximately 2000 m. In all aspects and on wind-loaded slopes numerous large and, in isolated cases, very large avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: These conditions will cause a rise in the danger of dry and moist avalanches in all aspects.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs: At intermediate and high altitudes a considerable avalanche danger will prevail.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1100 m snow has fallen. Over a wide area over a wide area 20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The wind was moderate in the vicinity of peaks.
The more recent wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant and generally at intermediate and high altitudes. They are to be found especially adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Wind and new snow above approximately 1100 m. The sometimes strong wind has transported the new snow significantly. In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust. Faceted weak layers exist in the old snowpack on steep shady slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Since yesterday evening, an average of 25-45 cm of fresh snow has fallen in the Dolomites above 1600 m and 35-55 cm in the Pre-Alps above 1700 m. Further precipitation is expected in the afternoon, snowfall above 1000 m, bringing up to 25 cm of fresh snow in the Dolomites above 2000 m and 35 cm in the Pre-Alps above 1500 m. With fresh snow, spontaneous avalanches of weakly cohesive snow are possible, which in some cases can even reach large sizes. The winds at high altitudes are blowing tensely from the southern quadrants and are creating new wind-blown snow deposits, which can be triggered already with a weak overload (e.g. by a single skier), and here too avalanches can reach large sizes. At altitudes between 1,000 and 1,400 m, where the snow has fallen wetter and on relatively warm ground, snow slide avalanches are possible. The avalanche danger is estimated to be Marked (Grade 3) above the forest line and Moderate (Grade 2) at lower altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The snowpack will become increasingly prone to triggering. Over a wide area new snow is lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs represent the main danger. This applies in particular in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
In all aspects and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation medium-sized to large avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and strong wind. Gliding avalanches are possible in particular on steep grassy slopes.
The new snow and wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: As a consequence of snowfall and the strong southwesterly wind, fresh snow drift accumulations will form. The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs that are forming in all aspects are bonding poorly with the old snowpack.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Some snow will fall over a wide area.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Large quantities of fresh snow and the wind-drifted snow of yesterday represent the main danger. In addition an appreciable danger of gliding avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow of yesterday and the extensive wind slabs can be released easily, even by a single winter sport participant, in all aspects above the tree line. Individual natural avalanches are further possible, especially in case of releases originating from very steep high-altitude leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are sometimes covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size in particular on very steep west, north and east facing slopes. Such avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular above approximately 2400 m. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 4 (high) the avalanche danger is a little higher.

On steep grassy slopes more frequent medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible, especially on sunny slopes below approximately 2400 m. In addition as the day progresses an increasing number of small and medium-sized loose snow avalanches are to be expected, in the event of solar radiation especially on extremely steep sunny slopes.

Backcountry touring and other off-piste activities call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1500 m. The strong wind has transported the new snow. As a consequence of the sometimes strong wind the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.

Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m: The new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations at high altitude. In some cases new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack, in particular on steep west and east facing slopes above approximately 2400 m, as well as on steep north facing slopes above approximately 2200 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The natural activity of slab avalanches will appreciably decrease. The conditions will prevent a rapid stabilisation of the snowpack. In addition further gliding avalanches are to be expected. Some loose snow avalanches are possible.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Backcountry touring calls for meticulous route selection. Even single backcountry tourers can release avalanches.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind was moderate at times in particular along the border with France and along the border with Switzerland.
As a consequence of wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed.
They can be released easily by a single winter sport participant, this also applies on steep slopes, caution is to be exercised in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
(--), in particular along the border with France. Remotely triggered avalanches are possible in isolated cases.
Natural avalanches: Dry slab avalanches and dry loose snow avalanches are still possible, especially on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
30 to 40 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days. The moderate wind has transported the new snow.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes. Numerous medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry slab avalanches have been released on wind-loaded slopes.
On Friday in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain small and medium-sized avalanches were released. Isolated whumpfing sounds and natural avalanches serve as an alarm sign.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The large quantity of fresh snow and the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released easily or naturally in all aspects. Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large natural avalanches are to be expected, especially in case of releases originating from very steep leeward starting zones. The avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are barely recognisable, even to the trained eye. Avalanches can also be triggered in the old snowpack and reach quite a large size.
On steep grassy slopes medium-sized gliding avalanches are possible.
The current avalanche situation calls for great caution and restraint.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 25 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday above approximately 1400 m. The strong wind has transported some snow.
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2400 m.
The new snow and wind slabs are poorly bonded with the old snowpack. Especially shady slopes above approximately 2400 m:
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
Some snow will fall on Saturday over a wide area.
Loose snow avalanches are possible on Sunday, but they can be quite large, in the regions exposed to a lot of new snow especially on very steep slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As the day progresses as a consequence of the snowfall there will be an increase in the danger of moist and wet avalanches to level 2 (moderate).

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Above approximately 1500 m snow has fallen. The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation caution is to be exercised in particular on steep slopes along the border with France.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area over a wide area 15 to 25 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Large-grained weak layers exist in the snowpack in particular on shady slopes. The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a sometimes moderate wind from westerly directions, sometimes deep wind slabs formed.
They can be released. The avalanche prone locations are to be found on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.
Natural avalanches: Dry avalanches are possible, but they will be mostly small, especially on extremely steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
20 to 30 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 2000 m.
The fresh snow as well as the wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack in particular on shady slopes.
The old snowpack is favourably layered.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The danger of natural avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: At elevated altitudes the avalanche prone locations are more widespread and the danger is level 2 (moderate).
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Above approximately 1500 m snow has fallen.
The fresh snow of the last two days and in particular the mostly small wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions. In the regions exposed to heavier precipitation this applies in particular on very steep slopes.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: As a consequence of new snow and wind a low danger of moist snow slides will be encountered in some localities.
Individual avalanche prone locations are to be found at intermediate and high altitudes and on very steep slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
As a consequence of a mostly light wind from westerly directions, small wind slabs formed.
These can in isolated cases be released by people.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on very steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain.
Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1900 m.
The old snowpack will be in most cases well bonded.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions, depending on the infuence of the wind.
At low and intermediate altitudes only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Weakly bonded old snow is to be evaluated with care and prudence. Precarious weak layers exist in the old snowpack in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Individual mostly small avalanches are possible above approximately 1800 m. This applies especially in gullies and bowls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack remains subject to considerable local variations. At high altitude only a little snow is lying. At high altitude mostly small wind slabs formed. In gullies and bowls the wind slabs are larger.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow and wind slabs at intermediate and high altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 2000 m. The mostly small wind slabs can be released in some cases in particular on very steep shady slopes above approximately 2300 m. This applies in particular adjacent to ridgelines and in pass areas in particular at high altitudes and in high Alpine regions.
Apart from the danger of being buried, restraint should be exercised as well in view of the danger of avalanches sweeping people along and giving rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The new snow is deposited on bare ground over a wide area. This applies in particular on sunny slopes, as well as at low and intermediate altitudes.
In some places new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
The old snowpack remains generally stable.
